text: Inchcailloch (; island of the old woman), burial place of Saint Kentigerna Caintigern (died 734), or Saint Kentigerna, was a daughter of Cellach Cualann, King of Leinster, and of Caintigern, daughter of Conaing Cuirre. Her feast is listed in the Aberdeen Breviary for 7 January. Her husband is said to have been Feriacus regulus of Monchestre. Mac Shamhrain identifies him with the Feradach hoa Artúr of Dál Riata, the possible grandson of King Arthur who signed the Cáin Adomnáin at Birr in 697 and supposes that he was a king in Dál Riata. Along with her brother St. Comgan and her son St. Fillan, the widowed Caintigern is said to have lived as a hermit, first in Strath Fillan, then in the Lennox, on the island of Inchcailloch on Loch Lomond. ==References== ==External links== * http://medievalscotland.org/kmo/AnnalsIndex/Feminine/Caintigern.shtml ==Sources== * Alan Orr Anderson, Early Sources of Scottish History A.D 500-1286, volume 1. Reprinted with corrections. Paul Watkins, Stamford, 1990. * Category:People from County Wicklow Category:734 deaths Category:8th- century Christian saints Category:Medieval Irish saints Category:8th-century Irish people Category:Female saints of medieval Ireland Category:8th-century Irish women Category:Year of birth unknown
title: Caintigern
